text.headline: Track the O.J. Simpson chase 20 years later
text.text: It's been 20 years since O.J. Simpson led police on an infamous low-speed chase in a white Bronco, when he was suspected of killing his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ron Goldman. (He was famously acquitted the following year.) Simpson had arranged to turn himself in on the morning of June 17, 1994, but never showed. Instead, he led police on a 35-mile-per-hour pursuit with his friend, "AC" Cowlings, driving the SUV. Simpson ultimately surrendered to authorities. This presentation outlines the major events of the day, when a nation became glued to the television set. All times and locations are approximate and based on available reports.

text.headline: 8:30 a.m.
text.text: Los Angeles Police Department officials contact Robert Shapiro, O.J. Simpson's lawyer, asking him to have his client surrender. About an hour later, Shapiro tells Simpson he will have to surrender to police that morning. (As reported by the L.A. Times)

text.headline: 11 a.m.
text.text: Simpson is scheduled to surrender at Parker Center in downtown Los Angeles.

text.headline: 12:35 p.m.
text.text: After Simpson and Shapiro fail to arrive at the Parker Center to surrender to authorities, three LAPD squad cars arrive at Robert Kardashian's home in the San Fernando Valley. There, police learn Simpson had left with his friend and former teammate Al Cowlings in a white Ford Bronco. (As reported by the L.A. Times)

text.headline: 1:50 p.m.
text.text: At a news conference in downtown Los Angeles, LAPD Cmdr. David Gascon tells the media that Simpson failed to surrender as scheduled, that the LAPD is unsure of Simpson's whereabouts, and that Simpson is considered a fugitive. (As reported by the L.A. Times)

text.headline: 2 p.m.
text.text: Police respond to 911 call at Nicole Brown Simpson's condo, after someone identified as her father asking people to call 911. About an hour later, a LAPD officer at Nicole Simpson's condominium tells reporters, "O.J. Simpson is not here." (As reported by the L.A. Times)

text.headline: 4 p.m.
text.text: At an afternoon news conference, L.A. County District Attorney Gil Garcetti says anyone helping Simpson to flee will be prosecuted as a felon and that prosecutors have not decided whether to seek the death penalty in the case. About 45 minutes later, police issue an arrest warrant for his former teammate, "AC" Cowlings. (As reported by the L.A. Times)

text.headline: 5 p.m.
text.text: At a news conference, longtime Simpson friend Robert Kardashian reads a letter reportedly from Simpson: "Don't feel sorry for me," ends the note. "I've had a great life, great friends. Please think of the real O.J. and not this lost person. Thanks for making my life special. I hope I helped yours. Peace and love. O.J."

text.headline: 5:51 p.m.
text.text: Simpson reportedly makes a 911 call from the cellular phone in his Ford Bronco. His location is traced to the 5 Freeway in Orange County near Lake Forest, where his ex-wife, Nicole, was buried Thursday.

text.headline: 5:56 p.m.
text.text: The California Highway Patrol begins pursuit after seeing Cowlings' white Ford Bronco heading south through Orange County on the 5 Freeway near El Toro, Calif.

text.headline: 7:25 p.m.
text.text: About 15 minutes after reaching the 91 Freeway, the pursuit of the white Ford Bronco reaches the 110 Freeway east of Torrance.

text.headline: 7:26 p.m.
text.text: LAPD Detective Tom Lange connects with Simpson on a cell phone.  (As reported by the L.A. Times)

text.headline: 7:46 p.m.
text.text: The white Ford Bronco continues north on the 405 Freeway in Torrance, encountering crowds standing on the roadway and overpasses.

media.caption: Motorists wave as police cars pursue the white Ford Bronco driven by Al Cowlings carrying fugitive murder suspect O.J. Simpson, on a 90-minute slow-speed car chase on June 17, 1994 on the 405 freeway in Los Angeles, California. Simpson's friend Cowlings eventually drove Simpson home, with Simpson ducked under the back passenger seat, to Brentwood where he surrendered after a stand-off with police.

text.headline: 7:55 p.m.
text.text: The white Ford Bronco exits the 405 Freeway at Sunset Boulevard.

text.headline: 7:57 p.m.
text.text: Simpson and Cowlings arrive at Simpson's Brentwood home and negotiations for surrender begin.

text.headline: 8:45 p.m.
text.text: The door to the white Ford Bronco opens. Simpson climbs out holding framed pictures of his family and is taken into custody. Minutes later, police issue an all-clear after taking Simpson into custody. (As reported by the L.A. Times)

text.headline: 9:37 p.m.
text.text: Simpson arrives at Parker Center in police custody.
